name: 6-nitro-2-phenyl-3H-indol-3-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3395
Reason: 6-nitro-2-phenyl-3H-indol-3-one has a melting point that we can predict by considering its structural components. Starting with the basic unit of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C, we have substantial structural components to consider. The nitro group introduces a strong withdrawing group, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50 °C. The phenyl group linked in place of a hydrogen atom raises the melting point due to molecular size and rigidity, estimated at around +20 °C. The indole ring itself contributes to the melting point due to its rigidity and pi-stacking interactions, estimated at around +20 °C. The ketone group introduces polar carbonyl interactions, contributing approximately +40 °C. The methyl group reduces the melting point by approximately -10 °C due to the reduced molecular weight and the absence of a hydrogen bonding potential.
